markups: ''The immediate ending of one player's turn due to a game event to start another player's turn.''

Many games divide the gameplay into turns in which one player can do actions. While many different ways of determining when a turn should end for one player and start for another, <style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style> describe the cases when failing specific actions immediately end the turn.

Rules for <style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style> exist in both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/American%20Football">American Football</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Basketball">Basketball</link></style> to regulate cases where possession of the ball changes. Although <style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style> happen when one team scores this is typically not referred to as a <style="CurrentLink">Turnover</style>. Being a fantasy version of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/American%20Football">American Football</link></style>, it may not be surprising that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl">Bloodbowl</link></style> (both in its original form and as a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl%20(computer%20game)">computer game</link></style>) also have rules for <style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style>. A difference here is however that several additional failure, e.g. failing tackles or falling when sprinting, causes <style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CrossFire:%20Rules%20&%20Organizations%20for%20Company%20Level%20WW2%20Gaming">CrossFire: Rules & Organizations for Company Level WW2 Gaming</link></style> is example of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Strategy%20Games">Strategy Game</link></style> with a <style="CurrentLink">Turnover</style> game mechanic.

<style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style> is one way of enacting <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> in games but one that occur as <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> for failed actions rather than due to a deterministic process. The actual implementation of a <style="CurrentLink">Turnover</style> can be seen as forcing <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style> on actions that remained to be done.

<style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style> are a form of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>. Since players are aware that failed actions can lead to <style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style> in games with this pattern, it forces them to do <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations and quite likely also <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> in which order to do actions.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Turnovers</style> become more or less certainties if players do enough actions that can fail and have this as a <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style>, the pattern gives rise to a soft version of <style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style>.
